SubTopics: Analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text, including how the major sections and text features (e.g., headings) contribute to the whole and to the development of the ideas.
Content: What is the MOST LIKELY reason the author included paragraph 1 of “The Teen Who Woke Up Her School”?

A.Choice: to emphasize how a lack of sleep affects teenagers

B.Choice: to demonstrate how committed Jilly was to her schoolwork

C.Choice: to highlight what caused Jilly to combat the school board's idea

D.Choice: to show that teenagers' attitudes about sleep can evolve over time

SubTopics: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 1 of “The Teen Who Woke Up Her School” in the box.
:box:So when her school board proposed switching her Columbia, Missouri, high school's start time from 7:50 a.m. to 7:20 a.m. — a full half hour earlier — she was outraged.
What is the MAIN purpose of the dashes in the sentence?

A.Choice: to emphasize that the words inside the dashes are important to the author's point

B.Choice: to signal that the words inside the dashes represent the author's opinion

C.Choice: to indicate the interruption of a process

D.Choice: to introduce a contrary point of view

SubTopics: Determine a text's central idea(s) and analyze its/their development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of a text.
Content: What does paragraph 2 of “The Teen Who Woke Up Her School” MAINLY reveal?

A.Choice: how complex Jilly's plan was

B.Choice: how unexpected Jilly's project was

C.Choice: how passionate Jilly was about her cause

D.Choice: how sympathetic Jilly was to other students

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Based on paragraphs 4-6 of “The Teen Who Woke Up Her School,” what do the words “gain steam” mean as they are used in paragraph 6?

A.Choice: change in form

B.Choice: fail to achieve goals

C.Choice: increase in popularity

D.Choice: stop making progress

SubTopics: Determine a text's central idea(s) and analyze its/their development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of a text.
Content: Which sentence BEST explains the main idea of the section WHY TEENS STRUGGLE in “The Teen Who Woke Up Her School”?

A.Choice: Without enough sleep, teenagers are unable to make quick decisions.

B.Choice: Teenagers' sleep patterns are affected by natural changes in their bodies.

C.Choice: Most teenagers are involved in too many activities to get the sleep they need.

D.Choice: According to research, teenagers' sleep habits play a role in how much they will grow.

SubTopics: Analyze the interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in a text (e.g., how ideas influence individuals or events, or how individuals influence ideas or events).
Content: What does paragraph 16 of “The Teen Who Woke Up Her School” MAINLY reveal about Jilly?

A.Choice: Jilly hoped that the school board would not interrupt her presentation with many challenging questions.

B.Choice: Jilly assumed that her lack of understanding of her subject would be exposed when she presented in front of the school board.

C.Choice: Jilly believed that her chance of success would be greatest if she presented information to the school board in an unbiased way.

D.Choice: Jilly worried that the school board would not take her presentation seriously unless they thought she was an accomplished student.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 7 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Based on paragraphs 3 and 4 of “Why Schools Are Struggling to Let Students Sleep In,” what is the MOST LIKELY meaning of the word skeptical as it is used in paragraph 4?

A.Choice: doubtful

B.Choice: hopeless

C.Choice: confused

D.Choice: disappointed

SubTopics: Analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text, including how the major sections and text features (e.g., headings) contribute to the whole and to the development of the ideas.
Content: What is the MAIN purpose of paragraphs 6 and 7 of “Why Schools Are Struggling to Let Students Sleep In”?

A.Choice: to present reasons for opposition to revised school hours

B.Choice: to highlight the influence that athletics has over school policies

C.Choice: to introduce the challenge of keeping teenagers occupied after the school day

D.Choice: to contrast reactions of parents and teenagers to proposed start times for schools

SubTopics: Analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text, including how the major sections and text features (e.g., headings) contribute to the whole and to the development of the ideas.
Content: Read the sentences from paragraph 8 of “Why Schools Are Struggling to Let Students Sleep In” in the box.
:box:They surveyed Fairfax students about sleep habits. They reduced bus expenses. They worked around concerns from community members.
What is the MAIN effect of the similar structure of the sentences?

A.Choice: It illustrates how dull the officials' tasks were.

B.Choice: It encourages admiration for the officials' positive attitudes.

C.Choice: It shows that the officials were overwhelmed by their duties.

D.Choice: It emphasizes how thorough the officials were in their planning.

SubTopics: Analyze the interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in a text (e.g., how ideas influence individuals or events, or how individuals influence ideas or events).
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
Based on “Why Schools Are Struggling to Let Students Sleep In,” which of the following was a challenge for communities that considered changing school hours?

A.Choice: informing the public about the details of the new schedule

B.Choice: making the different schedule work for other family members

C.Choice: proving that enough students were negatively affected by the old schedule

D.Choice: teaching students how to balance the new schedule with their daily activities

Content: Which of the following pairs of quotations BEST supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “That's when McClay learned about sleep phase delay ...” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “... making it biologically unfeasible for some teens to go to bed before 11 p.m. and wake up before 8 a.m ...” (paragraph 2)

C.Choice: “... McClay met with a group of parents, teachers and administrators to discuss a question that doctors have been posing for years ...” (paragraph 3)

D.Choice: “Starting classes at 8:30 or 9 a.m. might make it harder for parents to get to work on time ...” (paragraph 4)

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what a text states explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text, quoting or paraphrasing as appropriate.
Content: Based on BOTH articles, what did Jilly Dos Santos and Jodi McClay discover when they gathered more information about sleep?

A.Choice: Getting a healthy amount of exercise helps people sleep more soundly.

B.Choice: Reducing the amount of light in a bedroom can result in more relaxing dreams.

C.Choice: Limiting the pressures placed on young people can assist them in getting more rest.

D.Choice: Getting an adequate amount of sleep is necessary for students to think more clearly.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Analyze how two or more authors writing about the same topic shape their presentations of key information by emphasizing different evidence or advancing different interpretations of facts.
Content: Read the sentences from the articles in the box.

:box:• The school board decided that instead of making Jilly's high school's start time earlier, they would adjust the bus schedule and make the start time even later, at 8:55 a.m. (paragraph 17 of “The Teen Who Woke Up Her School”)

• During the process, they shared insights with the public and gave people a year to prepare for the change, which took effect in September. (paragraph 8 of “Why Schools Are Struggling to Let Students Sleep In”)
Based on the sentences, what is the MAIN difference between the tones of the two articles?

A.Choice: “The Teen Who Woke Up Her School” has an upbeat tone, while “Why Schools Are Struggling to Let Students Sleep In” is more neutral.

B.Choice: “The Teen Who Woke Up Her School” has an anxious tone, while “Why Schools Are Struggling to Let Students Sleep In” is more forceful.

C.Choice: “The Teen Who Woke Up Her School” has an aggressive tone, while “Why Schools Are Struggling to Let Students Sleep In” is more sympathetic.

D.Choice: “The Teen Who Woke Up Her School” has a realistic tone, while “Why Schools Are Struggling to Let Students Sleep In” is more dramatic.

SubTopics: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking; retain and further develop language skills learned in previous grades.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.
Write arguments (e.g., essays, letters to the editor, advocacy speeches) to support claims with clear reasons and relevant evidence.
Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.
Content:
:ibox:For this question, you will write an essay based on the passage(s). Your writing should:

• Present and develop a central idea.

• Provide evidence and/or details from the passage(s).

• Use correct grammar, spelling, and punctuation.

Based on “The Teen Who Woke Up Her School” and “Why Schools Are Struggling to Let Students Sleep In,” write an essay arguing that middle schools and high schools should have later start times. Be sure to use information from BOTH articles to develop your essay.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular elements of a story, poem, or drama interact (e.g., how setting shapes the characters or plot).
Content: Based on the stage directions in lines 6-9, which of the following words BEST describe Much and Little?

A.Choice: lazy and greedy

B.Choice: arrogant and critical

C.Choice: wasteful and disorganized

D.Choice: inconsiderate and untrustworthy

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning, tone, or mood, including the impact of repeated use of particular images.
Content: How does the reference to the spider's web in line 92 MOSTLY contribute to the central idea of the play?

A.Choice: A spider's web suggests a trap for those who fail to notice it.

B.Choice: A spider's web suggests a tool that is necessary for survival.

C.Choice: A spider's web symbolizes a project that is difficult to complete.

D.Choice: A spider's web represents a mistrust of those who lie to get an advantage.

SubTopics: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Content: Read the sentence from lines 96 and 97 in the box.
:box:(As EMPEROR is being helped into “coat,” EMPRESS moves downstage.)
What is the MOST LIKELY reason for the quotation marks around the word “coat”?

A.Choice: to suggest that the coat is not attractive

B.Choice: to emphasize the weight of the coat

C.Choice: to indicate that the coat is not real

D.Choice: to show dialogue about the coat

SubTopics: Analyze how particular elements of a story, poem, or drama interact (e.g., how setting shapes the characters or plot).
Content: What do lines 130 and 131 MOST LIKELY suggest about the Emperor?

A.Choice: He is hoping to say something kind about the robe in a creative way.

B.Choice: He is trying to use a clever approach to get more information about the robe.

C.Choice: He is hoping to try on the robe without acknowledging that he does not want to pay for it.

D.Choice: He is trying to show his expertise without revealing that he does not know much about designing the robe.

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what a text states explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text, quoting or paraphrasing as appropriate.
Content: Read lines 154-161 in the box.

:box:LITTLE: Watch out, sir, you're stepping on the train! (Alarmed, LORD jumps right.) No, no, not there! Get off! (LORD jumps left.) You're still standing on it!

LORD (Backing upstage in confusion): I'm dreadfully sorry!

EMPEROR (Glaring at LORD): Clumsy idiot! (To LITTLE) Has he ruined it with his dirty boots?

LITTLE: No harm has been done, but we'd better put away the robe. (MUCH and LITTLE carry “robe” to dress form.)
What do the lines MAINLY show?

A.Choice: how effective Much and Little's performance is

B.Choice: how disrespectful Much and Little are to others

C.Choice: how curious the Lord is about the robe's materials

D.Choice: how indecisive the Emperor can be toward those close to him

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning, tone, or mood, including the impact of repeated use of particular images.
Content: Read the lines from the play in the box.

:box:MUCH:  ... (Smiling slyly) — but I'll warrant that you never have been dressed as you will be tomorrow. (lines 166 and 167)

EMPEROR: (Exuberantly) Oh, I can hardly wait until tomorrow to show my people my new clothes! (lines 174 and 175)
What is the MAIN effect of the lines?

A.Choice: They heighten the conflict between the Emperor and Much.

B.Choice: They foreshadow a possible embarrassment for the Emperor.

C.Choice: They reveal a surprising similarity between the Emperor and Much.

D.Choice: They resolve a sense of uncertainty that has been bothering the Emperor.

SubTopics: Analyze how an author develops and contrasts the points of view of different characters or narrators in a text.
Content: The playwright develops the different points of view in the play MAINLY by contrasting character traits. Select the phrase that BEST completes each sentence.
THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
The playwright illustrates the

A.Choice: tailors' hardworking attitude.

B.Choice: tailors' deceitful actions.

C.Choice: Minister's clumsiness.

D.Choice: Minister's curiosity.

Content: Which of the following pairs of quotations BEST supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: fear of failing a challenge.

B.Choice: reluctance to betray their values.

C.Choice: efforts to protect their reputations.

D.Choice: attempts to reach an important goal.
